Real Analytic Functions

Definition

Let U⊆RU \subseteq \RU⊆R be an open set and f ⁣:U→R\func{f}{U}{\R}f:U→R be a function. We say that fff is real analytic on UUU if for every a∈Ua \in Ua∈U, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that

f(x)=∑n=0∞ca,n(x−a)nfor x∈B(a,r).f\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_{a,n}\p{x - a}^n \quad\text{for } x \in B\p{a, r}.f(x)=n=0∑∞​ca,n​(x−a)nfor x∈B(a,r).
Remark.

One thing important to keep in mind is that the coefficients can be different depending on the center aaa. For example, if f=0f = 0f=0 on (0,1)\p{0, 1}(0,1) and f=1f = 1f=1 on (2,3)\p{2, 3}(2,3), then fff is real analytic, but

f(x)=0+0+⋯on (0,1)f(x)=1+0+⋯on (2,3).\begin{aligned} f\p{x} &= 0 + 0 + \cdots \quad\text{on } \p{0, 1} \\ f\p{x} &= 1 + 0 + \cdots \quad\text{on } \p{2, 3}. \end{aligned}f(x)f(x)​=0+0+⋯on (0,1)=1+0+⋯on (2,3).​
Example 1.

11−x=∑n=0∞xn\frac{1}{1 - x} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n1−x1​=∑n=0∞​xn is real analytic on (−1,1)\p{-1, 1}(−1,1). (It's actually real analytic on (−∞,1)\p{-\infty, 1}(−∞,1), but of course, the power series expansion will be different from the above when a<−1a < -1a<−1.)
Theorem

Let fff be a real analytic function on an interval I⊆RI \subseteq \RI⊆R. Assume that the set E={x | f(x)=0}E = \set{x \st f\p{x} = 0}E={x∣f(x)=0} is non-empty and that there exists a0∈Ea_0 \in Ea0​∈E and a sequence ak∈E∖{a0}a_k \in E \setminus \set{a_0}ak​∈E∖{a0​} such that ak→a0a_k \to a_0ak​→a0​ (a0a_0a0​ is called an accumulation point of EEE). Then f=0f = 0f=0 on III.
Proof.

Claim: f=0f = 0f=0 in an open interval around a0a_0a0​.

Since fff is real analytic at a0a_0a0​, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that

f(x)=∑n=0∞cn(x−a0)nfor x∈B(a0,r).f\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n\p{x - a_0}^n \quad\text{for } x \in B\p{a_0, r}.f(x)=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−a0​)nfor x∈B(a0​,r).

Suppose f≠0f \neq 0f=0 on B(a0,r)B\p{a_0, r}B(a0​,r). Then at least one of the coefficients cnc_ncn​ must be non-zero or else the series expansion is just 000. Let n0n_0n0​ be the first number such that cn0≠0c_{n_0} \neq 0cn0​​=0. Then

f(x)=∑n=n0∞cn(x−a0)n=(x−a0)n0∑n=n0∞cn(x−a0)n−n0⏟≕ g(x).f\p{x} = \sum_{n=n_0}^\infty c_n\p{x - a_0}^n = \p{x - a_0}^{n_0} \underbrace{\sum_{n=n_0}^\infty c_n\p{x - a_0}^{n-n_0}}_{\eqqcolon\,g\p{x}}.f(x)=n=n0​∑∞​cn​(x−a0​)n=(x−a0​)n0​=:g(x)n=n0​∑∞​cn​(x−a0​)n−n0​​​.

Notice that

lim⁡n→∞∣cn(x−a0)n−n0∣1n=∣x−a0∣lim⁡n→∞∣cn∣1n\lim_{n\to\infty} \abs{c_n\p{x - a_0}^{n-n_0}}^{\frac{1}{n}} = \abs{x - a_0}\lim_{n\to\infty} \abs{c_n}^{\frac{1}{n}}n→∞lim​∣∣​cn​(x−a0​)n−n0​∣∣​n1​=∣x−a0​∣n→∞lim​∣cn​∣n1​

(the second limit exists since it's the reciprocal of the radius of convergence of fff at aaa, which is at least rrr). Thus, ggg is also real analytic at aaa, and in particular, ggg is continuous.

Since ak∈Ea_k \in Eak​∈E,

0=f(ak)=(x−a0)n0g(ak).0 = f\p{a_k} = \p{x - a_0}^{n_0} g\p{a_k}.0=f(ak​)=(x−a0​)n0​g(ak​).

Moreover, because ak≠a0a_k \neq a_0ak​=a0​ for any kkk, we can divide to get

g(ak)=0  ⟹  g(a0)=lim⁡k→∞g(ak)=0g\p{a_k} = 0 \implies g\p{a_0} = \lim_{k\to\infty} g\p{a_k} = 0g(ak​)=0⟹g(a0​)=k→∞lim​g(ak​)=0

by continuity of ggg. But

g(a0)=0  ⟹  cn0=0,g\p{a_0} = 0 \implies c_{n_0} = 0,g(a0​)=0⟹cn0​​=0,

a contradiction. Thus, cn=0c_n = 0cn​=0 for all nnn, so fff is 000 on B(a0,r)B\p{a_0, r}B(a0​,r).

Claim: The set A={a | f(x)=0 in a neighborhood of a}A = \set{a \st f\p{x} = 0 \text{ in a neighborhood of } a}A={a∣f(x)=0 in a neighborhood of a} is non-empty, open, and closed.

From the first claim, we already have a0∈Aa_0 \in Aa0​∈A, so AAA is non-empty.

To see that AAA is open, let a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, so by definition, there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that f=0f = 0f=0 on B(a,r)B\p{a, r}B(a,r). Since open balls are open, for any a′∈B(a,r)a' \in B\p{a, r}a′∈B(a,r), there exists r′>0r' > 0r′>0 such that B(a′,r′)⊆B(a,r)B\p{a', r'} \subseteq B\p{a, r}B(a′,r′)⊆B(a,r). But this means that f=0f = 0f=0 on B(a′,r′)B\p{a', r'}B(a′,r′). Since a′a'a′ was arbitrary, this shows B(a,r)⊆AB\p{a, r} \subseteq AB(a,r)⊆A, so AAA is open.

Finally, to see that AAA is closed, assume there exists a∈A‾∖Aa \in \cl{A} \setminus Aa∈A∖A. By definition, there exists a sequence bk∈A∖{a}b_k \in A \setminus \set{a}bk​∈A∖{a} such that bk→ab_k \to abk​→a. But notice that a,bk∈Ea, b_k \in Ea,bk​∈E by definition, so by the first claim, this means that a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, a contradiction. Thus, A=A‾A = \cl{A}A=A, so AAA is closed.

Claim: A=IA = IA=I, i.e., f=0f = 0f=0 on all of III.

AAA is open, and because AAA is closed, AcA^\compAc is also open. Moreover, A∪Ac=IA \cup A^\comp = IA∪Ac=I. Thus, because III is connected and AAA is non-empty, it follows that A=IA = IA=I. (Otherwise, if Ac≠∅A^\comp \neq \emptysetAc=∅, then III is the union of two disjoint, non-empty, and open sets, which would imply that III is disconnected.) □\square□

Inner Products

Definition

Let VVV be a real or complex vector space. Then an inner product ⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩\inner{\,\cdot\,, \,\cdot\,}⟨⋅,⋅⟩ is a function V×V→(R or C)V \times V \to \p{\R \text{ or } \C}V×V→(R or C) which is:

  1. (conjugate symmetric) ⟨x,y⟩=⟨y,x⟩‾\inner{x, y} = \overline{\inner{y, x}}⟨x,y⟩=⟨y,x⟩​
  2. (linear in the first argument) ⟨x+λy,z⟩=⟨x,y⟩+λ⟨y,z⟩\inner{x + \lambda y, z} = \inner{x, y} + \lambda \inner{y, z}⟨x+λy,z⟩=⟨x,y⟩+λ⟨y,z⟩
  3. (positive definite) If x≠0x \neq 0x=0, then ⟨x,x⟩∈(0,∞)\inner{x, x} \in \p{0, \infty}⟨x,x⟩∈(0,∞)
Example 2.

The dot product on Rn\R^nRn, i.e.,

x⋅y=∑i=1nxiyix \cdot y = \sum_{i=1}^n x_iy_ix⋅y=i=1∑n​xi​yi​

is an inner product on Rn\R^nRn. Recall that

x⋅y=∥x∥∥y∥cos⁡θ,x \cdot y = \norm{x} \norm{y} \cos{\theta},x⋅y=∥x∥∥y∥cosθ,

so intuitively, inner products allow us to talk about angles in more general vector spaces.
Lemma

The function

⟨f,g⟩=∫01f(x)g(x)‾ dx\inner{f, g} = \int_0^1 f\p{x} \overline{g\p{x}} \,\diff{x}⟨f,g⟩=∫01​f(x)g(x)​dx

defines an inner product on C([0,1])C\p{\br{0, 1}}C([0,1]). Thus,

∥f∥2≔⟨f,f⟩=(∫01∣f(x)∣2 dx)12\norm{f}_2 \coloneqq \sqrt{\inner{f, f}} = \p{\int_0^1 \abs{f\p{x}}^2 \,\diff{x}}^{\frac{1}{2}}∥f∥2​:=⟨f,f⟩​=(∫01​∣f(x)∣2dx)21​

defines a norm on C([0,1])C\p{\br{0, 1}}C([0,1]) called the L2L^2L2-norm.
Remark.

C([0,1])C\p{\br{0, 1}}C([0,1]) is not complete with respect to the L2L^2L2-norm.
Example 3.

Use Gram-Schmidt to find an orthonormal basis for V=span⁡{1,x}V = \span\set{1, x}V=span{1,x}, where the span is taken over R\RR.
Solution.

We can take e1=1e_1 = 1e1​=1 since 111 is already normalized. Then

u2=x−proj⁡e1(x)=x−⟨x,e1⟩e1.u_2 = x - \proj_{e_1}\p{x} = x - \inner{x, e_1}e_1.u2​=x−proje1​​(x)=x−⟨x,e1​⟩e1​.

Here,

⟨x,e1⟩=∫01x⋅1 dx=12,\inner{x, e_1} = \int_0^1 x \cdot 1 \,\diff{x} = \frac{1}{2},⟨x,e1​⟩=∫01​x⋅1dx=21​,

so u2=x−12u_2 = x - \frac{1}{2}u2​=x−21​. Now we just need to normalize it:

∥u2∥2=(∫01(x−12)2 dx)12=123  ⟹  e2=u2∥u2∥2=2x3−3.\norm{u_2}_2 = \p{\int_0^1 \p{x - \frac{1}{2}}^2 \,\diff{x}}^{\frac{1}{2}} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{3}} \implies e_2 = \frac{u_2}{\norm{u_2}_2} = 2x\sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3}.∥u2​∥2​=(∫01​(x−21​)2dx)21​=23​1​⟹e2​=∥u2​∥2​u2​​=2x3​−3​.

Thus,

{1,2x3−3}\boxed{\set{1, 2x\sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3}}}{1,2x3​−3​}​

is an orthonormal basis for VVV.
Example 4.

Find the function in V=span⁡{1,x}V = \span\set{1, x}V=span{1,x} that minimizes the L2L^2L2-distance to x2x^2x2.
Solution.

Recall that the minimizer is the orthogonal projection of x2x^2x2 to VVV. This is

proj⁡V(x2)=⟨x2,e1⟩e1+⟨x2,e2⟩e2,\proj_V\p{x^2} = \inner{x^2, e_1}e_1 + \inner{x^2, e_2}e_2,projV​(x2)=⟨x2,e1​⟩e1​+⟨x2,e2​⟩e2​,

where {e1,e2}\set{e_1, e_2}{e1​,e2​} is the orthonormal basis from the previous problem. Thus,

⟨x2,e1⟩=∫01x2⋅1 dx=13⟨x2,e2⟩=∫01x2(2x3−3) dx=32−33,\begin{gathered} \inner{x^2, e_1} = \int_0^1 x^2 \cdot 1 \,\diff{x} = \frac{1}{3} \\ \inner{x^2, e_2} = \int_0^1 x^2\p{2x\sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3}} \,\diff{x} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}, \end{gathered}⟨x2,e1​⟩=∫01​x2⋅1dx=31​⟨x2,e2​⟩=∫01​x2(2x3​−3​)dx=23​​−33​​,​

so the minimizer is

13+(32−33)(2x3−3).\boxed{\frac{1}{3} + \p{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3}}\p{2x\sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3}}}.31​+(23​​−33​​)(2x3​−3​)​.
